did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Augusta County (Va.) Deposition from a Chancery Suit, William Scott, etc. vs. Robert Harnsbarger, 1829

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Local government records collection, Augusta County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This item came to the Library of Virginia under accession number 42948.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Augusta County was named in honor of Augusta of Saxe-Gotha, wife of Frederick Louis, Prince of Wales, and mother of George III. It was formed from Orange County in 1738, but, because the region was sparsely inhabited, county government was not actually established there until 1745.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Augusta County (Va.) Deposition from a Chancery Suit, William Scott, etc. vs. Robert Harnsbarger, 1829. The document contains a sworn statement of two acting justices of the peace in Fleming County, Kentucky. The statement certifies a deposition taken in Kentucky and accepted as evidence in the chancery cause Scott vs. Harnsbarger in Augusta County, Virginia in 1829. The testimony itself is not included.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Augusta County Court Records can be found on microfilm at the Library of Virginia. Consult A Guide to Virginia County and City Records on Microfilm.
